Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 12:23PM KariLynn wrote: Deb, This is the hardest part. It will get better.  The PET is easy - you just lay there.  Is similar to a bone scan - not noisy like an MRI.  They will inject you them you have to sit in a dim room doing nothing (they doesn't want you to read because it makes your brain more active and can attract the dye according to the last nurse I had.) Take whatever you need to to get through the next few days - then it will be done and you can get going with the game plan.  It really will make you feel better to have all of the results in and have a plan. Keeping you in my prayers. Kari

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2008 09:33PM KariLynn wrote: Deb, We have all been where you are now.  I was worthless for at least a month after my dx.  The first time you start thinking, "I can do this" won't be until your tests are in and you know what you're fighting and you work out a treatment plan.  Allow yourself to be a basket case at least that long. The next time you'll get to take an easier breath will be when you get your first set of scans that show the treatment is working.  Then you really start thinking, ok, I can live with this. Allow yourself to "zone out" for awhile.  It's a normal reaction.  I think it was at least a month from my dx that I found this board and started "being strong."  A lot of that is fake it till you make it! If you need anti-depressants, talk to your doctor.  I took the wallow route for a month and that worked for me.

Posts.Title: Very bad report KariLynn roseg

Posts.Content: KariLynn wrote: I went to the onc Weds and was not good.  Don't feel like writing everything out so will copy an email I sent to family and friends. Hi all, Had my doctor appointment yesterday - did not get good news.  My liver counts are bad and I am starting to get slightly yellow - having liver failure.  Because of this we have to stop chemo as it damages the liver and mine can't take it. Doctor has referred me to Hospice (can give pain treatment but no other medical treatment.)  They provide end-of-life care and try to let me live to the highest quality of life that I can.  I have been assigned an RN who will check on me weekly (more if needed) and help with medical issues (will do blood draws so I don't have to go out  to the hospital.)  There's a social worker who works with patient, caregiver, and family counseling; and an aid who comes three times a week to help with grooming (sounds like I'm a poodle!)  They have delivered a hospital bed, cane, wheelchair and oxygen - I haven't needed that but they said better to have in case we  need it in the middle of the night. Fr. Tom came over last night and helped us talk to the kids about what was going on.  Was tough but he helped a lot and I think it was good. We have a vacation planned July 13-15 to go to El Dorado Lake.  Have rented a cabin that is near the swim area and looks like it will be fun.  My friend Renea and her family live there and I am looking forward to seeing her - haven't been up her way in years!  We've been trying to think of another place to go that the kids might enjoy, will probably just end up in Branson again... Other than this, I'm feeling pretty well - no real pain to speak of.  Tire easily and have no stamina, but have a lot of help so I get to sleep when I need it.  Thanks for all the thoughts and prayers - right now; it's the only medicine I can take!  Hope everyone is enjoying their summer - I hear it's hot out but have been in most of the time and am COLD!  Like the heat whe I get in it. Take care. Love, Kari If you can solve your problem, then what is the need of worrying? If you cannot solve it, then what is the use of worrying? Dx 6/2/2005, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, 14/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2007 04:10PM KariLynn wrote: I use the fentynl patches and those work well.  Have percocet for break-through.  Good luck getting it under control. Kari
Posts.Title: Pain from Bone Mets jonimb joanne1428

Posts.Content: KariLynn wrote: I went to the onc Weds and was not good.  Don't feel like writing everything out so will copy an email I sent to family and friends. Hi all, Had my doctor appointment yesterday - did not get good news.  My liver counts are bad and I am starting to get slightly yellow - having liver failure.  Because of this we have to stop chemo as it damages the liver and mine can't take it. Doctor has referred me to Hospice (can give pain treatment but no other medical treatment.)  They provide end-of-life care and try to let me live to the highest quality of life that I can.  I have been assigned an RN who will check on me weekly (more if needed) and help with medical issues (will do blood draws so I don't have to go out  to the hospital.)  There's a social worker who works with patient, caregiver, and family counseling; and an aid who comes three times a week to help with grooming (sounds like I'm a poodle!)  They have delivered a hospital bed, cane, wheelchair and oxygen - I haven't needed that but they said better to have in case we  need it in the middle of the night. Fr. Tom came over last night and helped us talk to the kids about what was going on.  Was tough but he helped a lot and I think it was good. We have a vacation planned July 13-15 to go to El Dorado Lake.  Have rented a cabin that is near the swim area and looks like it will be fun.  My friend Renea and her family live there and I am looking forward to seeing her - haven't been up her way in years!  We've been trying to think of another place to go that the kids might enjoy, will probably just end up in Branson again... Other than this, I'm feeling pretty well - no real pain to speak of.  Tire easily and have no stamina, but have a lot of help so I get to sleep when I need it.  Thanks for all the thoughts and prayers - right now; it's the only medicine I can take!  Hope everyone is enjoying their summer - I hear it's hot out but have been in most of the time and am COLD!  Like the heat whe I get in it. Take care. Love, Kari If you can solve your problem, then what is the need of worrying? If you cannot solve it, then what is the use of worrying? Dx 6/2/2005, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, 14/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Help!!!!!!! I need guidance RoxanneNJ31 RoxanneNJ31

Posts.Content: KariLynn wrote: I was to go to KU Sat for an MRI and today to meet with the neurosurgeon but cancelled both last week. Did an MRI here Tues and was going to take it to MDA when got a call yesterday confirming the dr appt today. Went ahead and said yes, I'll be there! Anyway, the lesions in the brain are shrinking and are no longer enhancing so she is even more convinced it is not cancer. I was scheduled to do a spinal MRI in KC but not at home and she still wants me to get that - said if it is MS it will show in the spine too. So, I will go to Houston next week and show them this mess then come home and get the spinal MRI and send it to KU. My next head MRI will be in 6 weeks - she says we should still watch the lesions - and we will double the time for the next scan with every stable one. The stuff on the skull is shrinking a little or is stable, I am cautiously optimistic for my PET in Houston. Have really been feeling good lately. If you can solve your problem, then what is the need of worrying? If you cannot solve it, then what is the use of worrying? Dx 6/2/2005, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, 14/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2007 11:25PM KariLynn wrote: STEP AWAY FROM THE LEDGE!!! Sorry - have always been better at bossing folks around than talking them down...  A lot of things show up on x-rays that turn out to be nothing.  I hope this is true in your case and you get that information quickly.  Take care, Kari
Posts.Title: CT Scan tomorrow...talk me down off my ledge! donnams jacqniel

Posts.Content: KariLynn wrote: I am SO, SO glad that I started the stage iv journey with hormone treatments because I am no match for the chemo!!  I hope the cancer cells are just as miserable! My life is:  Day 1, chemo.  Day 8, blood work.  Find out it has tanked and either have to get 2 units of blood or neupogen shots (or this week - BOTH! fun) Day 8-14 drive to the hospital to get a shot. Avoid any infectious people and places and raw fruits.  Day 15-21 relatively good - can come out of seclusion.  Day 22 start again. I get scans a week from Monday and I hope all of this has been worth it.  Had I started with chemo, I would have wanted to quit thinking this was going to be the rest of my life. Onc is trying to hit me with the hard stuff while I am in pretty good shape, not sure I'm loving this plan!! OK, I'm done bitching.  Most of you have troopered through this and I will too. If you can solve your problem, then what is the need of worrying? If you cannot solve it, then what is the use of worrying? Dx 6/2/2005, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, 14/25 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 04:32AM KariLynn wrote: Janis, wish you didn't need to be here.  A few nights ago when I couldn't sleep I was composing a message to you in my head to stop worrying so much - damn, I hate to be wrong about that.  I could still "win" with the biopsy but, if not, we are here for you and you will learn to live with this. I intended to start journals for the kids but three years later still have not!  Did try to make memories with them - as part of retail therapy, may I suggest a Disney cruise... Take it easy and enjoy your life, you and your family will remain in my prayers. Kari

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 08:06PM KariLynn wrote: Diarrhea is a potential side effect of Taxol.  Make sure she mentions it to the doctor (call if it's awhile before her next appt) to see what she can take.  It's important to keep her strength up and is hard to do that if everything keeps going out...
Posts.Title: Side effects with treament mimi1030 tooyoungtohavebc

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2008 01:10AM KariLynn wrote: I love  my port - named it Portia.  Has been in for 2.5 years.  For the CT scan, ask if they can give you water soluable crap to drink instead of the chalk.  They can mix it with juice and it is easier to get down (IMO).  I refuse to drink the chalk (would just throw it up, not much good there!)

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 07:24PM KariLynn wrote: Kenna, Sorry for your news.  I presented with bone mets 2 years ago so understand how overwhelming this is. Do more than pray for the best - plan for the best.  If you haven't sought out a second opinion from a breast specialist, I suggest you do.  Chances are your dr is doing everything right, but specialists are up on the most current treatment.  This isn't an immediate death sentence but it's nothing to play with either. Take care of yourself, Kari
